query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
13 Io non m’accorsi del salire in ella; 14 ma d’esservi entro mi fé assai fede 15 la donna mia ch’i’ vidi far più bella.

Please translate each line literally into English.
16 E come in fiamma favilla si vede, 17 e come in voce voce si discerne, 18 quand’ una è ferma e altra va e riede,
19 vid’ io in essa luce altre lucerne 20 muoversi in giro più e men correnti, 21 al modo, credo, di lor viste interne.
query.result:
16 And as a spark is seen in flame, 17 and as voice is distinguished from voice, 18 when one is fixed and another goes and returns,
19 I saw in her lights other lights 20 moving around, more and less swift, 21 in the manner, I believe, of their inner visions.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Di fredda nube non disceser venti, 23 o visibili o no, tanto festini, 24 che non paressero impediti e lenti
25 a chi avesse quei lumi divini 26 veduti a noi venir, lasciando il giro 27 pria cominciato in li alti Serafini;
28 e dentro a quei che più innanzi appariro 29 sonava ‘Osanna’ sì, che unque poi 30 di rïudir non fui sanza disiro.

Please translate each line literally into English.
31 Indi si fece l’un più presso a noi 32 e solo incominciò: «Tutti sem presti 33 al tuo piacer, perché di noi ti gioi.
query.result: 31 Then the one made himself closer to us 32 and alone began: “All are prompt 33 to your pleasure, because you rejoice in us.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Noi ci volgiam coi principi celesti 35 d’un giro e d’un girare e d’una sete, 36 ai quali tu del mondo già dicesti:
37 ‘Voi che ’ntendendo il terzo ciel movete’; 38 e sem sì pien d’amor, che, per piacerti, 39 non fia men dolce un poco di quïete».
query.result:
34 We turn with the celestial princes 35 of a circling and a turning and a thirst, 36 to whom you already said of the world:
37 ‘You who understanding move the third heaven’; 38 and they are so full of love, that, to please you, 39 will not be less sweet a little of quiet.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Poscia che li occhi miei si fuoro offerti 41 a la mia donna reverenti, ed essa 42 fatti li avea di sé contenti e certi,
43 rivolsersi a la luce che promessa 44 tanto s’avea, e «Deh, chi siete?» fue 45 la voce mia di grande affetto impressa.
query.result:
40 Afterwards, when my eyes were offered 41 to my lady reverently, and she 42 had made them content and certain of herself,
43 they turned to the light that was promised 44 so much, and “Oh, who are you?” was 45 my voice impressed with great affection.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 E quanta e quale vid’ io lei far piùe 47 per allegrezza nova che s’accrebbe, 48 quando parlai, a l’allegrezze sue!
49 Così fatta, mi disse: «Il mondo m’ebbe 50 giù poco tempo; e se più fosse stato, 51 molto sarà di mal, che non sarebbe.
query.result:
46 And how much and what I saw her do more 47 for new joy that increased, 48 when I spoke, to her joys!
49 Thus made, she said to me: “The world had me 50 down for a short time; and if it had been more, 51 much will be of evil, that would not be.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
52 La mia letizia mi ti tien celato 53 che mi raggia dintorno e mi nasconde 54 quasi animal di sua seta fasciato.
query.result: 52 My joy keeps you hidden to me 53 that radiates around me and hides me 54 almost an animal wrapped in its silk.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Assai m’amasti, e avesti ben onde; 56 che s’io fossi giù stato, io ti mostrava 57 di mio amor più oltre che le fronde.

Please translate each line literally into English.
58 Quella sinistra riva che si lava 59 di Rodano poi ch’è misto con Sorga, 60 per suo segnore a tempo m’aspettava,
61 e quel corno d’Ausonia che s’imborga 62 di Bari e di Gaeta e di Catona, 63 da ove Tronto e Verde in mare sgorga.
query.result:
58 That sinister shore that washes 59 of the Rhone after it is mixed with Sorgue, 60 for its lord waited for me in time,
61 and that horn of Ausonia that becomes dark 62 with Bari and Gaeta and Catona, 63 from where Tronto and Verde flow into the sea.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Fulgeami già in fronte la corona 65 di quella terra che ’l Danubio riga 66 poi che le ripe tedesche abbandona.
query.result: 64 Already shone on my forehead the crown 65 of that land that the Danube marks 66 after it abandons the German banks.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
67 E la bella Trinacria, che caliga 68 tra Pachino e Peloro, sopra ’l golfo 69 che riceve da Euro maggior briga,
70 non per Tifeo ma per nascente solfo, 71 attesi avrebbe li suoi regi ancora, 72 nati per me di Carlo e di Ridolfo,
73 se mala segnoria, che sempre accora 74 li popoli suggetti, non avesse 75 mosso Palermo a gridar: “Mora, mora!”.
query.result:
67 And the beautiful Trinacria, that surrounds 68 between Pachino and Peloro, above the gulf 69 that receives greater trouble from Euro,
70 not because of Typhon but because of rising sulfur, 71 would have awaited its kings still, 72 born to me of Charles and Ridolfo,
73 if evil lordship, that always afflicts 74 the subject peoples, had not moved 75 Palermo to cry: “Delay, delay!”.

76 And if my brother had foreseen this, 77 the avaricious poverty of Catalonia 78 would already flee, so that it would not offend them;
79 for truly it is necessary to provide 80 for him, or for others, so that to his boat 81 loaded with burden, no more burden is added.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
82 La sua natura, che di larga parca 83 discese, avria mestier di tal milizia 84 che non curasse di mettere in arca».
query.result: 82 Its nature, which of generous hand 83 descended, would have need of such skill 84 that it would not care to put [things] in a chest.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 «Però ch’i’ credo che l’alta letizia 86 che ’l tuo parlar m’infonde, segnor mio, 87 là ’ve ogne ben si termina e s’inizia,
88 per te si veggia come la vegg’ io, 89 grata m’è più; e anco quest’ ho caro 90 perché ’l discerni rimirando in Dio.
query.result:
85 Because I believe that the high joy 86 that your speaking infuses into me, my lord, 87 there where every good ends and begins,
88 through you is seen as I see it, 89 grateful to me it is more; and also this I hold dear 90 because you discern [it] contemplating in God.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
91 Fatto m’hai lieto, e così mi fa chiaro, 92 poi che, parlando, a dubitar m’hai mosso 93 com’ esser può, di dolce seme, amaro».
query.result: 91 You have made me happy, and thus make clear to me, 92 since, speaking, you have moved me to doubt 93 how it can be, from sweet seed, bitter.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
94 Questo io a lui; ed elli a me: «S’io posso 95 mostrarti un vero, a quel che tu dimandi 96 terrai lo viso come tien lo dosso.
query.result: 94 This I to him; and he to me: “If I can 95 show you a truth, to what you ask, 96 you will hold the face as you hold the back.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Lo ben che tutto il regno che tu scandi 98 volge e contenta, fa esser virtute 99 sua provedenza in questi corpi grandi.
query.result: 97 The good that all the realm that you ascend 98 turns and satisfies, makes to be virtue 99 its providence in these large bodies.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
100 E non pur le nature provedute 101 sono in la mente ch’è da sé perfetta, 102 ma esse insieme con la lor salute:
103 per che quantunque quest’ arco saetta 104 disposto cade a proveduto fine, 105 sì come cosa in suo segno diretta.
query.result:
100 And not only are the natures provided 101 in the mind that is perfect in itself, 102 but they together with their health:
103 for whatever this bow shoots 104 falls to a provided end, disposed, 105 as a thing directed in its sign.

106 If this were not, the heaven that you traverse 107 would produce its effects so, 108 that there would not be arts, but ruins;
109 and this cannot be, if the intellects 110 that move these stars are not lacking, 111 and lacking the first, which does not have them perfect.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Vuo’ tu che questo ver più ti s’imbianchi?». 113 E io: «Non già; ché impossibil veggio 114 che la natura, in quel ch’è uopo, stanchi».
query.result: 112 Do you want that this truth become whiter to you? 113 And I: Not indeed; because I see it impossible 114 that nature, when it is necessary, tires.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
115 Ond’ elli ancora: «Or dì: sarebbe il peggio 116 per l’omo in terra, se non fosse cive?». 117 «Sì», rispuos’ io; «e qui ragion non cheggio».
query.result: 115 Then he again: “Now say: would it be worse 116 for man on earth, if he were not a citizen?” 117 “Yes,” I responded; “and here reason I do not seek.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
118 «E puot’ elli esser, se giù non si vive 119 diversamente per diversi offici? 120 Non, se ’l maestro vostro ben vi scrive».
query.result: 118 And can he be, if down below one does not live 119 differently for different offices? 120 Not, if your master writes to you well.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
121 Sì venne deducendo infino a quici; 122 poscia conchiuse: «Dunque esser diverse 123 convien di vostri effetti le radici:
124 per ch’un nasce Solone e altro Serse, 125 altro Melchisedèch e altro quello 126 che, volando per l’aere, il figlio perse.
query.result:
121 Thus he was leading up to this point; 122 then he concluded: “Therefore it is necessary that the roots 123 be of different effects from yours:
124 for one is born Solon and another Xerxes, 125 another Melchizedek and another the one 126 who, flying through the air, lost his son.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 La circular natura, ch’è suggello 128 a la cera mortal, fa ben sua arte, 129 ma non distingue l’un da l’altro ostello.
query.result: 127 The circular nature, which is a seal 128 to the mortal wax, does well its art, 129 but does not distinguish one dwelling from another.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Quinci addivien ch’Esaù si diparte 131 per seme da Iacòb; e vien Quirino 132 da sì vil padre, che si rende a Marte.
query.result: 130 From here it happens that Esau departs 131 through seed from Jacob; and Quirinus comes 132 from so vile a father, who surrenders to Mars.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
133 Natura generata il suo cammino 134 simil farebbe sempre a’ generanti, 135 se non vincesse il proveder divino.
query.result: 133 Nature generated would do its path 134 similarly always to the generators, 135 if not divine providence overcame.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 Or quel che t’era dietro t’è davanti: 137 ma perché sappi che di te mi giova, 138 un corollario voglio che t’ammanti.

Please translate each line literally into English.
139 Sempre natura, se fortuna trova 140 discorde a sé, com’ ogne altra semente 141 fuor di sua regïon, fa mala prova.
query.result: 139 Always nature, if it finds fortune 140 discordant to itself, as every other seed 141 outside its region, makes a bad test.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
142 E se ’l mondo là giù ponesse mente 143 al fondamento che natura pone, 144 seguendo lui, avria buona la gente.
query.result: 142 And if the world down there put its mind 143 to the foundation that nature places, 144 following it, the people would be good.

145 But you twist it to religion 146 so that he is born to gird on the sword, 147 and you make kings of one who is from preaching;
148 whence your trace is outside the road.
